message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Strictly local phonological processes
Paper Abstract: This dissertation identifies a strong computational property of phonological and morphological processes with local triggers. It is shown that the input-output mapping that underlies these processes can be modeled with Strictly Local (SL) functions, a previously undefined class of subregular relations. The SL functions, which are divided into two proper subclasses of subsequential functions (the Input SL functions and Output SL functions) are given an automata-theoretic characterization by combining the properties of subsequential transduction (Mohri, 1997) and the Strictly Local formal languages (McNaughton and Papert, 1971; Rogers and Pullum, 2011; Rogers et al., 2013). Importantly, the property of strict locality is independent of and compatible with both rule- and constraint-based grammatical formalisms, since it holds of the input-output mappings that both formalisms describe. The range of processes that are shown to be Strictly Local includes substitution, deletion, insertion, synchronic metathesis, local partial reduplication, and general affixation. This computational property aids in identifying the set of 'phonologically possible' processes within the larger set of logically possible processes. In addition, a learning algorithm that provably learns the class of ISL functions by using strict locality as an inductive principle is presented. These combined contributions to typology and learning demonstrate how computational analysis can enhance our understanding of the nature of locality in phonological processes.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the web search results, I found that "subsequential transduction" appears to be related to **sequence transduction** in machine learning contexts. Here's what the search revealed:

The idea of encoder-decoder sequence transduction had been developed in the early 2010s, and it's a fundamental concept in modern deep learning. Seq2seq maps an input sequence into a real-numerical vector by using a neural network (the encoder), and then maps it back to an output sequence using another neural network (the decoder).

The term "sequence transduction" is used to describe the process of transforming one sequence into anothersequence. This concept became especially important in language translation, image captioning, conversational models, speech recognition, and text summarization.

However, I should note that the search results do not contain specific information about "subsequential transduction" as a distinct technical term. If you're looking for more specialized or niche information about this concept, it may refer to a specific technique or variant within the broader field of sequence transduction that isn't well-documented in widely available sources.

Web search results for query: "Automata theory"

Links: [{"title":"Automata theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automata_theory"},{"title":"Introduction to Automata Theory, Languages, and Computation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Introduction_to_Automata_Theory,_Languages,_and_Computation"},{"title":"Tree (automata theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tree_(automata_theory)"},{"title":"Category:Automata theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Automata_theory"},{"title":"Theory of computation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theory_of_computation"},{"title":"Cellular automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cellular_automaton"},{"title":"Krohn-Rhodes theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Krohn–Rhodes_theory"},{"title":"Learning automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Learning_automaton"},{"title":"Hybrid automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybrid_automaton"},{"title":"Finite-state machine - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Finite-state_machine"}]

## Automata Theory

Automata theory is the study of abstract machines and automata, as well as the computational problems that can be solved using them.(no content)It is a theory in theoretical computer science with close connections to cognitive science and mathematical logic.

### Key Concepts

An automaton (automata in plural) is an abstract self-propelled computing device which follows a predetermined sequence of operations automatically.(no content)An automaton with a finite number of states is called a finite automaton (FA) or finite-state machine (FSM).(no content)Automata theory is closely related to formal language theory. In this context, automata are used as finite representations of formal languages that may be infinite.

### Applications

Automata play a major role in the theory of computation, compiler construction, artificial intelligence, parsing and formal verification.(no content)In computer science, finite-state machines are widely used in modeling of application behavior (control theory), design of hardware digital systems, software engineering, compilers, network protocols, and computational linguistics.

### Historical Development

The theory of abstract automata was developed in the mid-20th century in connection with finite automata.(no content)1956 saw the publication of Automata Studies, which collected work by scientists including Claude Shannon, W. Ross Ashby, John von Neumann, Marvin Minsky, Edward F. Moore, and Stephen Cole Kleene. With the publication of this volume, "automata theory emerged as a relatively autonomous discipline".

Links: [{"title":"Affix - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affix"},{"title":"Morphological derivation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morphological_derivation"},{"title":"Inflection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inflectional_morpheme"},{"title":"Morphology (linguistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morphology_(linguistics)"},{"title":"Suprafix - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suprafix"},{"title":"Root (linguistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Root_word"},{"title":"Affix grammar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affix_grammar"},{"title":"English prefix - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Com-"},{"title":"Odia grammar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oriya_morphology"},{"title":"Tommo So - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_639:dto"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about affixation in morphology:

## Definition and Basic Concept

In linguistics, an affix is a morpheme that is attached to a word stem to form a new word or word form.(no content)Changing a word by adding a morpheme at its beginning is called prefixation, in the middle is called infixation, and at the end is called suffixation.

## Types of Affixes

The main two categories are derivational and inflectional affixes. 

**Derivational Affixes**: Derivational affixes, such as un-, -ation, anti-, pre- etc., introduce a semantic change to the word they are attached to. Examples include adding un- to "happy" to create "unhappy" or -ly to "slow" to create "slowly."

**Inflectional Affixes**: Inflectional affixes introduce a syntactic change, such as singular into plural (e.g. -(e)s), or present simple tense into present continuous or past tense by adding -ing, -ed to an English word.

## Role in Word Formation

Morphemes include roots that can exist as words by themselves, but also categories such as affixes that can only appear as part of a larger word.(no content)Root morphemes are the building blocks for affixation and compounds.

Affixation is a fundamental morphological process across many languages and is central to understanding how words are constructed and how meaning is conveyed through word structure.

**Inflectional Affixes**: Inflectional affixes introduce a syntactic change, such as singular into plural (e.g. -(e)s), or present simple tense into present continuous or past tense by adding -ing, -ed to an English word.

## Role in Word Formation

Morphemes include roots that can exist as words by themselves, but also categories such as affixes that can only appear as part of a larger word.(no content)Root morphemes are the building blocks for affixation and compounds.

Links: [{"title":"Formal language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_language"},{"title":"Formal semantics (natural language) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_semantics_(natural_language)"},{"title":"Alternation (formal language theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alternation_(formal_language_theory)"},{"title":"Local language (formal language) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Local_language_(formal_language)"},{"title":"Cone (formal languages) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cone_(formal_languages)"},{"title":"Formal grammar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_linguistics"},{"title":"Pattern language (formal languages) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pattern_language_(formal_languages)"},{"title":"List of formal language and literal string topics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_formal_language_and_literal_string_topics"},{"title":"Specification language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Specification_language"},{"title":"Omega language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Omega_language"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of formal languages based on the search results:

## Definition

In logic, mathematics, computer science, and linguistics, a formal language is a set of strings whose symbols are taken from a set called "alphabet".(no content)The alphabet of a formal language consists of symbols that concatenate into strings (also called "words").

## Key Characteristics

A formal language is often defined by means of a formal grammar such as a regular grammar or context-free grammar.(no content)The field of formal language theory studies primarily the purely syntactic aspects of such languages—that is, their internal structural patterns.

## Applications

Formal languages have diverse practical applications:

- In computer science, formal languages are used, among others, as the basis for defining the grammar of programming languages and formalized versions of subsets of natural languages.

- In computational complexity theory, decision problems are typically defined as formal languages, and complexity classes are defined as the sets of the formal languages that can be parsed by machines with limited computational power.

- In logic and the foundations of mathematics, formal languages are used to represent the syntax of axiomatic systems, and mathematical formalism is the philosophy that all of mathematics can be reduced to the syntactic manipulation of formal languages.

## Historical Context

Formal language theory sprang out of linguistics, as a way of understanding the syntactic regularities of natural languages.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Reduplication linguistics"

Links: [{"title":"Reduplication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reduplication"},{"title":"Contrastive focus reduplication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contrastive_focus_reduplication"},{"title":"Clitic doubling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clitic_doubling"},{"title":"Seesaw - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seesaw"},{"title":"Apophony - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apophony"},{"title":"Bunuba language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bunuba_language"},{"title":"Tikopia language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tikopia_language"},{"title":"Reduplication in Russian - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reduplication_in_Russian"}]

## Reduplication in Linguistics

In linguistics, reduplication is a morphological process in which the root or stem of a word, part of that, or the whole word is repeated exactly or with a slight change.

### Functions and Uses

It is used in inflections to convey a grammatical function, such as plurality or intensification, and in lexical derivation to create new words.(no content)It is often used when a speaker adopts a tone more expressive or figurative than ordinary speech and is also often, but not exclusively, iconic in meaning.

### Semantic Meanings

According to Edward Sapir's classic observation, reduplication is "generally employed, with self-evident symbolism, to indicate such concepts as distribution, plurality, repetition, customary activity, increase of size, added intensity, continuance."

### Types of Reduplication

Full reduplication involves a reduplication of the entire word, while partial reduplication involves a reduplication of only part of the word.(no content)Reduplication is often described phonologically in one of two ways: either as reduplicated segments (sequences of consonants/vowels) or as reduplicated prosodic units (syllables or moras).

### Linguistic Distribution

It is found in a wide range of languages and language groups, though its level of linguistic productivity varies.

Links: [{"title":"Phonological rule - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phonological_rule"},{"title":"Phonological development - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phonological_development"},{"title":"Phonology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phonology"},{"title":"Morphophonology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morphophonology"},{"title":"Phonological awareness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phonological_awareness"},{"title":"Phonics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phonics"},{"title":"Speech production - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speech_production"},{"title":"Breton mutations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Breton_mutations?variant=zh-cn"},{"title":"Voice (phonetics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voiced"},{"title":"Phonetics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phonetically"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about phonological processes:

## Overview

Phonological processes are systematic transformations that children apply when their words differ from adult forms. More broadly, phonological processes include patterns like reduplication, final consonant deletion, and cluster reduction, which reflect typical strategies children use to simplify adult words as their phonological systems develop.

## Types of Phonological Processes

Phonological rules can be divided into four main types: Assimilation, when a sound changes one of its features to be more similar to an adjacent sound; Dissimilation, when a sound changes one of its features to become less similar to an adjacent sound; and Insertion, when an extra sound is added between two others. Additionally, there is Deletion, in which sounds are not pronounced.

## Examples

The English plural rule demonstrates assimilation—the -s becomes voiced or voiceless depending on whether or not the preceding consonant is voiced. Another example of insertion occurs in the English plural rule: when the plural morpheme z is added to "bus," a short vowel (the schwa, [ə]) is inserted between [s] and the [z].

## Natural Phonology Theory

In Natural Phonology, phonology is based on a set of universal phonological processes that interact with one another; those that are active and those that are suppressed is language-specific.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about phonological processes:

## Overview

Phonological processes are systematic transformations that children apply when their words differ from adult forms. More broadly, phonological processes include patterns like reduplication, final consonant deletion, and cluster reduction, which reflect typical strategies children use to simplify adult words as their phonological systems develop.

## Types of Phonological Processes

Phonological rules can be divided into four main types: Assimilation, when a sound changes one of its features to be more similar to an adjacent sound; Dissimilation, when a sound changes one of its features to become less similar to an adjacent sound; and Insertion, when an extra sound is added between two others. Additionally, there is Deletion, in which sounds are not pronounced.

## Examples

The English plural rule demonstrates assimilation—the -s becomes voiced or voiceless depending on whether or not the preceding consonant is voiced. Another example of insertion occurs in the English plural rule: when the plural morpheme z is added to "bus," a short vowel (the schwa, [ə]) is inserted between [s] and the [z].

## Natural Phonology Theory

In Natural Phonology, phonology is based on a set of universal phonological processes that interact with one another; those that are active and those that are suppressed is language-specific.

Links: [{"title":"Metathesis (linguistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metathesis_(linguistics)"},{"title":"Metathesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metathesis"},{"title":"Quantitative metathesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantitative_metathesis"},{"title":"Talk:Metathesis (linguistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Metathesis_(linguistics)"},{"title":"Slavic liquid metathesis and pleophony - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slavic_liquid_metathesis_and_pleophony"},{"title":"Epenthesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epenthesis"},{"title":"Talk:Slavic liquid metathesis and pleophony - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Slavic_liquid_metathesis_and_pleophony"},{"title":"Speech error - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speech_error"},{"title":"Metaphony - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metaphony"},{"title":"Metalinguistics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metalinguistics"}]

## Metathesis in Linguistics

Metathesis is the transposition of sounds or syllables in a word or of words in a sentence. The term comes from Greek and literally means "to put in a different order."

### Basic Definition

Most commonly, it refers to the interchange of two sounds or syllables. It's a linguistic phenomenon where the order of phonological units gets reversed within a word or utterance.

### Examples and Applications

Metathesis occurs in various languages and contexts:

- **French Verlan**: Deliberate metathesis occurs extensively in the informal French pattern of speech called verlan, where new words are created from existing words by reversing the order of syllables.

- **American Sign Language**: In American Sign Language, several signs which have pre-specified initial and final locations can have the order of these locations reversed in phonological contexts. For example, the sign DEAF can have its locations reversed depending on the preceding sign.

- **Slavic Languages**: The Slavic liquid metathesis refers to the phenomenon of metathesis of liquid consonants in the Common Slavic period, affecting syllables in which the Proto-Slavic liquid consonants *r and *l occurred in a coda position.

- **Historical Examples**: In Greek, for example, *cháryō became chaírō "I am glad," showing the transposition of sounds.

### Relation to Other Phonological Processes

Metathesis is distinct from other sound changes. Related processes include epenthesis (the addition of a sound), paragoge (the addition of a sound to the end of a word), and prothesis (the addition of a sound to the beginning of a word).

Based on the search results, here's information about phonological deletion, insertion, and substitution:

## Phonological Operations

These are three fundamental types of phonological processes used in linguistics:

### **Insertion**
Insertion occurs when an extra sound is added between two others.(no content)For example, in English, when the plural morpheme z is added to "bus," a short vowel (the schwa, [ə]) is inserted between [s] and the [z].(no content)In phonology, epenthesis means the addition of one or more sounds to a word, especially in the first syllable, the last syllable, or between two syllabic sounds in a word.

### **Deletion**
In linguistics, an elision or deletion is the omission of one or more sounds (such as a vowel, a consonant, or a whole syllable) in a word or phrase.(no content)The opposite process of insertion, in which one or more sounds are removed, is referred to as syncope or elision.

### **Substitution**
In linguistic contexts, substitution is one of the minimum single-character edits (along with insertions and deletions) required to change one word into another.

## Context in Phonological Rules
A phonological rule is a formal way of expressing a systematic phonological or morphophonological process in linguistics, and phonological rules are commonly used in generative phonology as a notation to capture sound-related operations and computations the human brain performs when producing or comprehending spoken language.

Here are the search results for "Computational linguistics":

## Overview

Computational linguistics is an interdisciplinary field concerned with the computational modelling of natural language, as well as the study of appropriate computational approaches to linguistic questions.(no content)In general, computational linguistics draws upon linguistics, computer science, artificial intelligence, mathematics, logic, philosophy, cognitive science, cognitive psychology, psycholinguistics, anthropology and neuroscience, among others.

## History

The field overlapped with artificial intelligence since the efforts in the United States in the 1950s to use computers to automatically translate texts from foreign languages, particularly Russian scientific journals, into English.(no content)After the failure of rule-based approaches, David Hays coined the term in order to distinguish the field from AI and co-founded both the Association for Computational Linguistics (ACL) and the International Committee on Computational Linguistics (ICCL) in the 1970s and 1980s.

## Major Organizations and Publications

The ACL organizes several of the top conferences and workshops in the field of computational linguistics and natural language processing.(no content)Computational Linguistics is a quarterly peer-reviewed open-access academic journal in the field of computational linguistics. It is published by MIT Press for the Association for Computational Linguistics (ACL).

Here are the search results for "Computational linguistics":

## Overview

Computational linguistics is an interdisciplinary field concerned with the computational modelling of natural language, as well as the study of appropriate computational approaches to linguistic questions.(no content)In general, computational linguistics draws upon linguistics, computer science, artificial intelligence, mathematics, logic, philosophy, cognitive science, cognitive psychology, psycholinguistics, anthropology and neuroscience, among others.

## History

The field overlapped with artificial intelligence since the efforts in the United States in the 1950s to use computers to automatically translate texts from foreign languages, particularly Russian scientific journals, into English.(no content)After the failure of rule-based approaches, David Hays coined the term in order to distinguish the field from AI and co-founded both the Association for Computational Linguistics (ACL) and the International Committee on Computational Linguistics (ICCL) in the 1970s and 1980s.

## Major Organizations and Publications

The ACL organizes several of the top conferences and workshops in the field of computational linguistics and natural language processing.(no content)Computational Linguistics is a quarterly peer-reviewed open-access academic journal in the field of computational linguistics. It is published by MIT Press for the Association for Computational Linguistics (ACL).


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the web search results, I found some related mathematical concepts, but "subregular functions" as a standalone term doesn't appear in the search results. However, I did find several related function types that are worth noting:

**Related Concepts:**

1. **Sublinear functions**: In linear algebra, a sublinear function, also called a quasi-seminorm, on a vector space is a real-valued function with some of the properties of a seminorm.

2. **Subharmonic functions**: Subharmonic and superharmonic functions are important classes of functions used extensively in partial differential equations, complex analysis and potential theory.

3. **Submodular functions**: These are set functions with specific mathematical properties related to "diminishing returns."

4. **Subadditivity**: Subadditivity is an essential property of some particular cost functions and is generally a necessary and sufficient condition for the verification of a natural monopoly.

The search results also mention "subregular orbit" in the context of algebraic geometry, but this appears to be a different concept.

Web search results for query: "Strictly local formal languages"

Links: [{"title":"Local language (formal language) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Local_language_(formal_language)"},{"title":"Formal language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_language"},{"title":"Formal grammar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_grammars"},{"title":"LL grammar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LL1_grammar"},{"title":"Category:Formal languages - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Formal_languages"},{"title":"Template talk:Formal languages and grammars - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template_talk:Formal_languages_and_grammars"},{"title":"Regular grammar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regular_grammar"},{"title":"Automata theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automata_theory"},{"title":"Chomsky hierarchy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chomsky_hierarchy"},{"title":"Purely functional programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Purely_functional_programming"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about strictly local formal languages:

## Definition

A local language is a formal language for which membership of a word in the language can be determined by looking at the first and last symbol and each two-symbol substring of the word.

## Formal Characterization

A language L over an alphabet A is defined to be local if there are subsets R and S of A and a subset F of A×A such that a word w is in L if and only if the first letter of w is in R, the last letter of w is in S and no factor of length 2 in w is in F.

## Relationship to Other Language Classes

A local language is 2-testable, where a k-testable language is one for which membership of a word w in L depends only on the prefix and suffix of length k and the set of factors of w of length k.(no content)A local language is recognized by a local automaton, a particular kind of deterministic finite automaton.

## Closure Properties

The family of local languages over A is closed under intersection and Kleene star, but not complement, union or concatenation.

Local languages are a special class of regular languages with restricted expressive power, useful in formal language theory and computational linguistics.

Web search results for query: "Learning algorithm machine learning"

Links: [{"title":"Machine learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning"},{"title":"Outline of machine learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_machine_learning"},{"title":"Supervised learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supervised_learning"},{"title":"Algorithmic learning theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algorithmic_learning_theory"},{"title":"Category:Machine learning algorithms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Machine_learning_algorithms"},{"title":"Active learning (machine learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active_learning_(machine_learning)"},{"title":"Deep learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_learning"},{"title":"Online machine learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Online_machine_learning"},{"title":"Incremental learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Incremental_learning"},{"title":"Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of learning algorithms in machine learning based on the search results:

## What is Machine Learning?

Machine learning (ML) is a field of study in artificial intelligence concerned with the development and study of statistical algorithms that can learn from data and generalise to unseen data, and thus perform tasks without explicit instructions.

## Types of Learning Algorithms

Modern-day Machine Learning algorithms are broken into 3 algorithm types: Supervised Learning Algorithms, Unsupervised Learning Algorithms, and Reinforcement Learning Algorithms.

### Supervised Learning
In machine learning, supervised learning (SL) is a type of machine learning paradigm where an algorithm learns to map input data to a specific output based on example input-output pairs. This process involves training a statistical model using labeled data, meaning each piece of input data is provided with the correct output.(no content)Current Supervised Learning Algorithms have objectives of classification and regression.

### Unsupervised Learning
Current Unsupervised Learning Algorithms have objectives of clustering, dimensionality reduction, and association rule.

### Reinforcement Learning
In machine learning and optimal control, reinforcement learning (RL) is concerned with how an intelligent agent should take actions in a dynamic environment in order to maximize a reward signal.

## Deep Learning
Fundamentally, deep learning refers to a class of machine learning algorithms in which a hierarchy of layers is used to transform input data into a progressively more abstract and composite representation.

## Applications
ML finds application in many fields, including natural language processing, computer vision, speech recognition, email filtering, agriculture, and medicine.

Machine learning (ML) is a field of study in artificial intelligence concerned with the development and study of statistical algorithms that can learn from data and generalise to unseen data, and thus perform tasks without explicit instructions.

## Types of Learning Algorithms

Modern-day Machine Learning algorithms are broken into 3 algorithm types: Supervised Learning Algorithms, Unsupervised Learning Algorithms, and Reinforcement Learning Algorithms.

### Supervised Learning
In machine learning, supervised learning (SL) is a type of machine learning paradigm where an algorithm learns to map input data to a specific output based on example input-output pairs. This process involves training a statistical model using labeled data, meaning each piece of input data is provided with the correct output.(no content)Current Supervised Learning Algorithms have objectives of classification and regression.

### Unsupervised Learning
Current Unsupervised Learning Algorithms have objectives of clustering, dimensionality reduction, and association rule.

### Reinforcement Learning
In machine learning and optimal control, reinforcement learning (RL) is concerned with how an intelligent agent should take actions in a dynamic environment in order to maximize a reward signal.

## Deep Learning
Fundamentally, deep learning refers to a class of machine learning algorithms in which a hierarchy of layers is used to transform input data into a progressively more abstract and composite representation.

## Applications
ML finds application in many fields, including natural language processing, computer vision, speech recognition, email filtering, agriculture, and medicine.

Links: [{"title":"Phonological rule - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phonological_rule"},{"title":"Feeding order - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feeding_order"},{"title":"Talk:Phonological rule - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Phonological_rule"},{"title":"Morphophonology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morphophonology"},{"title":"Cluster reduction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cluster_reduction"},{"title":"Underlying representation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Underlying_representation"},{"title":"Alternation (linguistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alternation_(linguistics)"},{"title":"Bleeding order - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bleeding_order"},{"title":"Phonological change - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phonological_change"},{"title":"Vowel harmony - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vowel_Harmony"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of phonological rules:

## Definition

A phonological rule is a formal way of expressing a systematic phonological or morphophonological process in linguistics.(no content)Phonological rules are commonly used in generative phonology as a notation to capture sound-related operations and computations the human brain performs when producing or understanding speech.

## How They Work

Phonological rules are commonly represented using formal rewrite rules and describe what sound is changed, what the sound changes to, and where the change happens. A well-known example is intervocalic alveolar flapping: the stop consonants /t/ and /d/ only become a flap in between two vowels, where the first vowel is stressed and the second is stressless.

## Key Characteristics

Phonological rules are language-specific, apply even to new words (productivity), and speakers apply them without being aware of it and acquire them early in life without explicit teaching.

## Types of Rules

Assimilation occurs when a sound changes one of its features to be more similar to an adjacent sound, such as in the English plural rule where the -s becomes voiced or voiceless depending on whether the preceding consonant is voiced.(no content)Dissimilation occurs when a sound changes one of its features to become less similar to an adjacent sound.

Links: [{"title":"Morphophonology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morphophonology"},{"title":"Morphological typology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morphological_typology"},{"title":"Phonology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phonology"},{"title":"Morpheme - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morpheme"},{"title":"Haplology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haplogy"},{"title":"Trique languages - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_639:trs"},{"title":"Yurij Yakovlevitch Glazov - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yurij_Yakovlevitch_Glazov"},{"title":"Category:Linguistic morphology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Linguistic_morphology"},{"title":"Category:Phonology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Phonology"},{"title":"Hungarian grammar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hungarian_grammar"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about morphophonology:

## Definition

Morphophonology (also morphophonemics or morphonology) is the branch of linguistics that studies the interaction between morphological and phonological or phonetic processes.(no content)Its chief focus is the sound changes that take place in morphemes (minimal meaningful units) when they combine to form words.

## Core Concepts

Morphophonology bridges the gap between morphology and phonology, offering insights into the dynamic interactions between word formation and sound patterns.(no content)When morphemes combine, they influence each other's sound structure (whether analyzed at a phonetic or phonemic level), resulting in different variant pronunciations for the same morpheme.

## Analytical Approach

Morphophonological analysis often involves an attempt to give a series of formal rules or constraints that successfully predict the regular sound changes occurring in the morphemes of a given language. Such a series of rules converts a theoretical underlying representation into a surface form that is heard.

## Historical Development

The origins of morphophonology trace back to the early 20th century with foundational works in structural linguistics. Notable contributions include Roman Jakobson's insights into phonological alternations and Chomsky and Halle's The Sound Pattern of English (1968), which formalized the relationship between phonology and morphology within generative grammar.

## Examples

Inflected and agglutinating languages may have extremely complicated systems of morphophonemics. Common examples include:

- Consonant gradation, found in some Uralic languages such as Finnish, Estonian, Northern Sámi, and Nganasan
- Vowel harmony, which occurs in varying degrees in languages all around the world, notably Turkic languages
- Ablaut, found in English and other Germanic languages. Ablaut is the phenomenon wherein stem vowels change form depending on context, as in English sing, sang, sung.

Here's an overview of finite-state transducers based on the search results:

## What is a Finite-State Transducer?

A finite-state transducer (FST) is a finite-state machine with two memory tapes: an input tape and an output tape.(no content)This contrasts with an ordinary finite-state automaton, which has a single tape.

## Key Characteristics

An FST is a type of finite-state automaton that maps between two sets of symbols.(no content)While an FSA defines a formal language by defining a set of accepted strings, an FST defines a relation between sets of strings.(no content)A transducer transduces (i.e., translates) the contents of its input tape to its output tape, by accepting a string on its input tape and generating another string on its output tape.

## Practical Applications

Web search results for query: "Assimilation phonology"

Links: [{"title":"Assimilation (phonology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assimilation_(phonology)"},{"title":"Talk:Assimilation (phonology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Assimilation_(linguistics)"},{"title":"American Sign Language phonology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Sign_Language_phonology"},{"title":"Ukrainian phonology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ukrainian_phonology"},{"title":"Phonological rule - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phonological_rule"},{"title":"Consonant voicing and devoicing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consonant_voicing_and_devoicing"},{"title":"Assimilation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assimilation"},{"title":"Consonant harmony - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consonant_harmony"},{"title":"Category:Assimilation (linguistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Assimilation_(linguistics)"},{"title":"Coarticulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coarticulation"}]

## Assimilation in Phonology

Based on the search results, here's an overview of assimilation phonology:

### Definition

In phonology, assimilation is a sound change in which some phonemes (typically consonants or vowels) change to become more similar to other nearby sounds.(no content)This process is common across languages and can happen within a word or between words.

### Types of Assimilation

Assimilation can be categorized in several ways:

**By Direction:**
- If a sound changes with reference to a following segment, it is traditionally called "regressive assimilation".
- Changes with reference to a preceding segment are traditionally called "progressive".

**By Completeness:**
Assimilation occurs in two different types: complete assimilation, in which the sound affected by assimilation becomes exactly the same as the sound causing assimilation, and partial assimilation, in which the sound becomes the same in one or more features but remains different in other features, such as place of articulation.

### Common Examples

In English "handbag" (/ˈhændbæɡ/), the [n] often shifts to [m] in rapid speech, becoming /ˈhæmbæɡ/, because [m] and [b] are both bilabial (produced with both lips), and their places of articulation are similar.(no content)Although all four occur, changes in regard to a following adjacent segment account for most assimilatory changes and virtually all of the regular ones. Similarly, assimilations to an adjacent segment are far more frequent than assimilations to a nonadjacent one.

Links: [{"title":"Constraint grammar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constraint_grammar"},{"title":"Model-theoretic grammar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model-theoretic_grammar"},{"title":"Lexical functional grammar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lexical_functional_grammar"},{"title":"Optimality theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimality_theory"},{"title":"Head-driven phrase structure grammar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Head-driven_phrase_structure_grammar"},{"title":"Generalized phrase structure grammar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generalised_phrase_structure_grammar"},{"title":"Generative grammar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generative_grammar"},{"title":"Cognitive grammar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_grammar"},{"title":"Context-free grammar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Context-free_grammar"},{"title":"Locality (linguistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Locality_(linguistics)"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about constraint-based grammar linguistics:

## Overview

Constraint-based grammars, also known as model-theoretic grammars, contrast with generative grammars in the way they define sets of sentences: they state constraints on syntactic structure rather than providing operations for generating syntactic objects.(no content)Constraint based grammars are based around defining certain syntactic processes as ungrammatical for a given language and assuming everything not thus dismissed is grammatical within that language.

## Key Characteristics

A model-theoretic grammar simply states a set of conditions that an object must meet, and can be regarded as defining the set of all and only the structures of a certain sort that satisfy all of the constraints.(no content)One benefit of model-theoretic grammars over generative grammars is that they allow for gradience in grammaticality. A structure may deviate only slightly from a theory or it may be highly deviant.

## Major Approaches

Several important constraint-based grammar frameworks exist:

1. **Lexical Functional Grammar (LFG)**: LFG is a constraint-based grammar framework in theoretical linguistics that posits several parallel levels of syntactic structure, including a phrase structure grammar representation of word order and constituency, and a representation of grammatical functions such as subject and object, similar to dependency grammar.

2. **Head-Driven Phrase Structure Grammar (HPSG)**: HPSG is a highly lexicalized, constraint-based grammar developed by Carl Pollard and Ivan Sag.

3. **Generalized Phrase Structure Grammar (GPSG)**: GPSG is a framework for describing the syntax and semantics of natural languages that is a type of constraint-based phrase structure grammar based around defining certain syntactic processes as ungrammatical for a given language.

Links: [{"title":"Generative grammar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generative_grammar"},{"title":"Generative Phonology: Description and Theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generative_Phonology:_Description_and_Theory"},{"title":"Phonology in Generative Grammar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phonology_in_Generative_Grammar"},{"title":"Phonology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phonology"},{"title":"Joan Bybee - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joan_Bybee"},{"title":"Phonological rule - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phonological_rule"},{"title":"The Sound Pattern of English - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Sound_Pattern_of_English"},{"title":"Autosegmental phonology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autosegmental_phonology"},{"title":"Phoneme - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phoneme"},{"title":"Feeding order - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feeding_order"}]

Here's what I found about generative phonology:

## Overview

Generative phonology originally focused on rewrite rules, in a system commonly known as SPE Phonology after the 1968 book The Sound Pattern of English by Chomsky and Morris Halle.

## Key Characteristics

Chomsky and Halle present a view of phonology as a linguistic subsystem, separate from other components of the grammar, that transforms an underlying phonemic sequence according to rules and produces as its output the phonetic form that is uttered by a speaker.(no content)In that view, phonological representations are sequences of segments made up of distinctive features. The features describe aspects of articulation and perception, are from a universally fixed set and have the binary values + or −.

## Phonological Rules

Phonological rules are commonly used in generative phonology as a notation to capture sound-related operations and computations the human brain performs when producing or comprehending spoken language.(no content)Phonological rules describe how a speaker goes from the abstract representation stored in their brain, to the actual sound they articulate when they speak.

## Theoretical Developments

In the 1990s, this approach was largely replaced by Optimality theory, which was able to capture generalizations called conspiracies which needed to be stipulated in SPE phonology.(no content)Some major successor theories include autosegmental phonology, lexical phonology and optimality theory.

Based on the web search results, here's information about subsequential transducers and finite-state transducers:

## Finite-State Transducers

A finite-state transducer (FST) is a finite-state machine with two memory tapes, following the terminology for Turing machines: an input tape and an output tape.(no content)An FST is a type of finite-state automaton (FSA) that maps between two sets of symbols.

## Subsequential Transducers

A subsequential (single-valued) binary transducer is a transducer that maps sequences of events to sequences of effectors. The term "subsequential" refers to the property of being single-valued, meaning each input maps to at most one output, which contrasts with general transducers that may produce multiple outputs for a single input.

## Key Characteristics

An FSA defines a formal language by defining a set of accepted strings, while an FST defines a relation between sets of strings. An FST will read a set of strings on the input tape and generate a set of relations on the output tape.(no content)Finite-state transducers are often used for phonological and morphological analysis in natural language processing research and applications. Pioneers in this field include Ronald Kaplan, Lauri Karttunen, Martin Kay and Kimmo Koskenniemi.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

**Paper Classification**: **Contribution** - This paper proposes novel computational methods and theories, including Strictly Local (SL) functions, automata-theoretic characterizations, and a provable learning algorithm.

**Total Triples Extracted**: 15 entities representing the key technologies and methodologies in the paper.

- **Concepts**: 7 (Formal Language, Automata Theory, Morphophonology, Generative Grammar, Constraint Grammar, Local Language, Mealy Machine)
- **Methods**: 6 (Phonological Rule, Metathesis, Reduplication, Affix, Machine Learning, Assimilation)
- **Tools**: 1 (Finite-State Transducer)
- **Tasks**: 1 (Computational Linguistics)

### Key Relations:
- **Uses**: 14 triples (showing how the paper builds on existing work)
- **Proposes**: 1 triple (Machine Learning - the novel learning algorithm presented)
